awd_titl_txt: Intercellular Signaling in Pollen Tube Reception
awd_abstract_narration:
How do cells sense and establish communication with other cells in order to allow for beneficial or compatible interactions as opposed to harmful interactions? Plant pollination is an excellent system for gaining insight into this question because intercellular communication between male and female tissues is critical for the recognition of compatible pollen. In plants a pollen tube (PT) grows from a pollen grain that has landed on the surface of a flower's female reproductive tissue. The tube extends through that tissue towards the egg-containing ovary. Upon entering the ovary the tube stops growing and bursts open, releasing sperm that fertilize an egg, which in turn develops into a seed.  In order to deliver the sperm cells to the ovary, the PT must sense that it has arrived at the right place and change  from tip-growth to explosive release of the sperm it contains. This project seeks to determine the molecular signals that communicate to a PT that it has entered the ovary and must stop growing and release its sperm. 

Female gametophytic mutations in FERONIA (FER), a receptor-like kinase, and NORTIA (NTA), a member of the MILDEW RESISTANCE LOCUS O (MLO) family of 7-transmembrane proteins, cause PTs to continue growing inside of the receptive synergid instead of rupturing to release the sperm, indicating that these genes form part of a signaling network. This project is aimed at further elucidation of the molecular mechanisms used for communication between the synergid and PT during PT reception, using NTA as the anchor molecule. Synergids are highly specialized cells whose sole function is to communicate with PTs. Experiments will be performed to define the cell biology of the synergid cells before, during and after PT reception and to determine which domains are necessary for NTA localization and function and to determine how NTA fits into the dynamic cellular changes that occur during PT reception. The second goal of the project is to identify new members of the PT reception pathway and determine how they act in the signaling pathway. Enhancer and suppressor mutants of the gene nta will be characterized for roles in PT reception and NTA will be used as bait in yeast-2-hybrid screens to identify other members of the pathway. The results of this project will provide a clearer picture of the signaling pathway involved in PT reception and may also be transformative in our understanding of how self/non-self recognition takes place.  A graduate student, post-doc, and undergraduate student will be trained in the fields of plant genetics and cell biology during this project. Students in a cell biology lab taught by the Principal Investigator will investigate proteins that are predicted to be involved in PT reception in an inquiry-based lab module and an outreach program will be conducted to encourage rural Oklahoma high schools to incorporate plant science research in their curricula.

Intellectual Merit

            The overarching question in this project was "How do cells sense and establish communication with other cells to allow beneficial invasions and prevent harmful invasions?" Plant pollination is an excellent system for gaining insight into this question because it involves a series of intercellular communication pathways between male and female tissues. Proper control of this communication pathway is crucial for plant reproductive fitness. The first step of pollination is the recognition of compatible pollen by the female stigma cells so that pollen tubes will germinate and grow through the transmitting tract. While growing through the stigma and transmitting tract, the pollen tubes receive signals from the female tissues and become competent to respond to attractive signals from the ovules, which contain the female gametophytes. Finally, the pollen tube enters the female gametophyte and releases the sperm cells so that double fertilization can occur to produce viable seeds. In order to deliver the sperm cells to the female gametes, the pollen tube must sense that it has arrived at the right place and change its growth pattern from tip-growth to explosive growth as it invades the synergid, a specialized female gametophytic cell that emits signals to attract the pollen tube and serves as the gateway to the female gametes. In this project, we investigated the cell and molecular events that are necessary for successful pollen tube reception. We showed that pollen tube arrival at the synergid triggers a change in subcellular localization of a membrane protein, NORTIA (NTA), from the Golgi to a specialized membrane region called the filiform apparatus. This subcellular event is specific to the NTA protein and not just a reorganization of all cellular compartments. The molecular function of NTA is not known, but related MLO proteins have been implicated in regulation of cell death during pathogen invasion. We tested the hypothesis that filiform-apparatus localized NTA might function to induce cell death by artificially inducing filiform apparatus accumulation in the absence of a signal from an arriving pollen tube. This constitutive accumulation of NTA had no effect on cell death of the synergid. By preventing filiform apparatus accumulation by adding a Golgi retention signal to NTA, we determined that filiform apparatus accumulation of NTA is both necessary and sufficient for its role in pollen tube reception. We also used a forward genetics screen to identify enhancers and suppressors of the nta mutant pollen tube reception phenotype to find new genes involved in pollen tube reception. We identified a membrane protein of unknown function that interacts with NTA and leads to nta-like pollen tube reception defects when mutated. We also identified a pollen tube-expressed cytoplasmic kinase that plays a role in mediating the pollen tube?s bursting response to the signals from the synergids. The kinase mutant pollen tube bursts more easily in nta mutant ovules, indicating that changes to the physiology/cell biology of the pollen tube affect the ability to achieve successful delivery of the sperm cells so that a seed can be produced.

Broader Impacts

            Knowledge about the basic mechanisms of pollination and their relationships to biotic and abiotic stress and signaling mechanisms is required for engineering plants that will be able to produce seeds in extreme climates.  Our research on pollen tube reception revealed a complex interplay between the synergid cells and the physiology of the pollen tube that could potentially be exploited to increase successful pollination in extreme environments. To broaden participation of underrepresented groups and training of the next generation of scientists, a range of early career scientists were trained and mentored as part of the project. Two postdocs, four graduate students, and five undergraduates participated in the project. Three of the students are first-generation college students and four are from underrepresented minorities. The five undergraduate students contributed to the project by designing and constructing MLO-GUS vectors, transforming plants, and determining GUS localization patterns; performing site-directed mutagenesis on the NTA gene and testing if the variants could complement the nta mutation, and making domain-swap constructs. This participation resulted in undergraduates being co-authors on three publications that resulted from this project. Four of the undergraduates are pursuing STEM careers as graduate students or laboratory technicians. To improve STEM participation at the high school level, five high school students were mentored on projects related to pollination as part of the Purdue Pre-College Molecular Agriculture Summer Internship program (three of the students came to Purdue as Plant Science majors and one of them is now an undergraduate researcher in the Kessler lab). In addition, 35 high school teachers in the Purdue Agribusiness Science Academy's Botany and Plant Pathology Workshop were taught a pollen germination and pollen tube growth experiment and other ideas for experiments related to pollination that could be performed in high school labs to improve K-12 exposure to plant biology and pollination-related concepts.
